reviewText: Although I loved Bette Davis and Susan Hayward together in this movie, everything else was a disapointment. Mike Conners and Joey Heatherton were just awful and the movie just did not flow well. Sad because it had all the potential for a really good movie. Only reason to watch is to see 2 great actresses together. What a waste of their talent!
summary: Only One Reason to See This Movie
Title: N/A

reviewText: I am not going to comment on the merits (or lack of) of this film.  After all,  everyone else already has, and chacun à son got.  Suffice it to say that the Davis camp will want it for Bette and the Hayward camp for Susan.  And there might even be some folks out there who'll want it because of Mike Connors and/or Joey Heatherton,  after all, when it comes to movie fans, stranger, more bizarre things have been known to happen.  I myself love both leading ladies, with a definite preference and proclivity for Miss Davis, who gave us such magnificent treasures over her long, prolific career.  What I wish to comment on is a very distracting flaw in the soundtrack of this release.  The music and sound effects track is several decibels higher than the dialog track.  Every time background music comes in, it does so at a deafening volume.  Sound effects are also overly loud.  When the telephone rings in the film, it rings so thunderously it seems like it's ringing right next to your ears.  This same lack of sound equalization is present on Olive Films' DVD release of Harlow.  Olive is to be commended for finally bringing to DVD several long out of print films.  Some are from the Paramount catalog, a company that, shamefully, has done absolutely nothing with its classic product.  However, the person and/or persons doing the re-mastering for these releases need to be aware of this incongruence in volume levels between the music and dialog tracks.  It makes for a very unpleasant viewing experience and it needs to be corrected in future releases or it will mar the enjoyment of them also.  I sincerely hope Olive's upcoming Summer and Smoke doesn't suffer from this same equalization malady.  That said, I strongly urge Olive Films to continue its work licensing these lost gems and I hope that they will consider giving us other Paramount oversights like Samson and Delilah, The Secret of the Incas, and Omar Khayyam.  Also on my wish list, and I am sure I am not alone in this, are Something for Everyone, The Empty Canvas (La Noia), A House is not a Home,  Les amitiés particulières (This Special Friendship), De Eso No Se Habla (I Don't Want to Talk About It), Back Street, and the 1973 TV version of the musical Applause with Lauren Bacall and Larry Hagman.  Is Olive up to these challenges?
summary: DIVINE TRASH + BETTE + SUSAN!  WHO COULD ASK FOR ANYTHING MORE?

reviewText: This is a big expensive turkey. Mike Connors is a second rate leading man and Joey Heatherton simply whines and whinges as the trigger-happy daughter who kills her mother's boyfriend. This turgid melodrama somehow makes boring the real-life story of Lana Turner's daughter shooting her mother's beau, upon which this soap opera is clearly based. Bette is effective in an underwritten role as Susan Hayward's imperious mother  -  but even she gets monotonous. Susan Hayward, in the lead, at least works hard to carry the film and she's worth watching. She invokes "I Want to Live" meets "Valley of the Dolls" - entering, exiting, shaking her hair, driving cars fast, screaming, crying, does she slap a face (?), looking into the distance cynically. It's Susan's show.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Bette Davis sinks her teeth into her role...and devours it with a style glorious to behold."-Judith Christ, The New York Herald TribuneWhen fiery Academy Award - winning actresses Bette Davis and Susan Hayward sqaure off in the same movie, they better have a film worthy of their pyrotechnics. That's just what they found in Where Love Has Gone, a torrid story of passion, lies and murder based on Harold Robbins' sensational bestseller.Hayward plays a famed sculptress who lives by no rules but her own. Davis portrays her domineering mother. Mike Connors (TV's Mannix) is her estranged husband. And Joey Heatherton costars as Hayward and Connors' daughter, who brings all three generations into conflict when she's accused of murdering her mother's gigolo lover. Possibly inspired by the notorious Lana Turner - Johnny Stompanato case, WHere Love Has Gone is melodrama at its most riverting and watchable.
summary: Bette Davis is Where Love Has Gone

reviewText: ...I JUST DON'T GIVE A DAMN!"So goes Susan Hayward's harangue as she received a phone call saying her drunk of a husband is passed out and can't drive himself home... AGAIN!  This movie is indeed a good story that definitely keeps you interested, plus it has many fabulous camp momemts already described by other reviewers.  Not to mention some great scenery of San Francisco, mod 60s architecture, and the tour de force performances of Susan Hayward and Bette Davis.  Any "Valley of the Dolls" fan can easily see that Susan was well onto her way to playing Helen Lawson as she delivers her performance here.  Not to be missed!

reviewText: Where Love Has Gone has Bette Davis in it and this is reason enough to buy it. But then there is the great Susan Hayward and you weant to pay double for this DVD, finally released in widescreen, on VHS for a long time in regualr version.The film is that Lana Turner story all done up in color and Cinemascope, with loud furniture, loud costumes, and Bette Davis in deluxe fashions with a matronly, very atractive wig, as Susan's mother.Susan Hayward, for her part, is dressed in silk and has huge bracelets and earrings. And then there is the story: Bette Davis as Susan's mother, and Susan defying her, and Bette swinging back at Susan with lines like, "My little Valerie(Susans's name in the film)will always do what I tell her to do. Won't you dear?" Susan: "Oh mothwer. leave me aloooone!" In that voice of hers.It also has the acting of Joey Heatherton, an actress worse than many current sirens, but necessary here. You believe she murdered someone, and could possibly strike again.There is too a huge opening and a wonderful title song, and big gaudy credits. But then there is Bette Davis and her final lines, and these cannot be missed. She shows everyone how to do it.

reviewText: File this  trashy  soap opera based on Harold Robbins' sordid, tawdry, best-seller under "guilty pleasure." Trouble is, after you've watched divas Susan Hayward and Bette Davis share the screen (in a plot "inspired" by the Hollywood scandal of Lana Turner's daughter, Cheryl Crane, stabbing Lana's latest lover, Johnny Stompanato, to death), you'll likely be feeling more guilt than pleasure. ! Screenwriter John Michael Hayes also wrote Joan Crawford's campy classic "Torch Song." I was hoping that "Love" might also offer some campy fun. Alas, it does not.The names and locations have been changed, obviously so Lana Turner and/ or other parties involved in the infamous real-life events would not sue. Susan Hayward portrays Valerie Hayden, a successful, sexually active sculptress with an artistocratic, domineering mother (Bette Davis). Valerie's agent ("Star Trek's" DeForest Kelly) calls her a "pagen alley-cat." After Valerie's 15 year-old daughter Danielle (Joey Heatherton) stabs her boyfriend to death (with a chisel, no less!), her ex-husband Luke Miller (Mike Connors) returns. In a series of lengthy and progressively boring flashbacks, we see how Valerie and Luke's marriage went to hell. War hero Luke was emasulated by Valerie's success and his controlling mother-in-law. The marriage crumbles under "self-pity, booze, and recriminations." Luke slaps Valerie and tries to rape her. Valerie  avoids this by telling Luke he wasn't the first man she had that night!  Enraged Luke screams at her, "You're not a woman, you're a disease!" No wonder Valerie runs off to a "Sex-ational" nightclub to have fun. But , wait!  We haven't even covered the fact that  15 year old Danielle (played as a pouting sex-kitten by an obviously  over-age and unconvincing Joey Heatherton) is not a virgin (Gasp!) and she wrote sexually explicit love letters to her mother's boyfriend before she killed him!Connors and Kelly somehow manage to hold their own on screen opposite Hayward and Davis. But Hayward and Davis are all anybody cares about.  A typical scene between Hayward and Davis is this: Hayward says, "When you're dying of thirst, you'll drink from a mud-hole." To which Davis responds, "You've devoted your life to mud and flith." Bette Davis gives her usual "Bette Davis performance." Which is: she chews the scenery for all its worth and thinks that increasingly annoying affectations and mannerisms amount to "Great Acting." (Meryl Streep obviously thinks the same thing. too!) Susan Hayward is the only one who maintains her dignity in all this mess. Lana Turner probably played the real trial for maximum drama, but Hayward sensibly and shrewdly underplays her courtroom scene.  I was delighted, however, when Hayward screamed at an over-the-top Davis, "WILL YOU SHUT UP FOR ONCE?" Wherever love has gone, I don't want to go there again.
summary: "YOU'VE DEVOTED YOUR LIFE TO MUD AND FLITH."

reviewText: Bette Davis is fantastic in the slick trash that is this film....true soap opera crapola with some nice touches worthy of an Ed Wood film.... I guess that's why I love it.... The theme song is perfect for the story that follows, and the supporting cast does an admirable job at filling in the cracks....beautifully done.... The audio and video are very good....give it a try....

reviewText: I bought this on VHS, thinking it would at least be campy in parts, but instead it is just plain dull. No fireworks even with Susan Hayward and Bette Davis aboard. The ending is very unsatisfying as is the rest of the film. Do yourself a favor and skip this soap opera junk. If it's 1960s Susan Hayward you want, get Valley of The Dolls. Bette Davis fans would be better off with Hush Hush Sweet Charlotte or Dead Ringer, both from the same era as Where Love Has Gone, but are far better films.

reviewText: I enthusiastically bought my copy of "Where Love Has Gone" on DVD yesterday after wearing out the VHS tape. I am sorely disappointed in the DVD. There are no extras: not even subtitles ! Maybe my copy is defective but the volume fades in and out several times during the film. The picture quality is better than the VHS, but sometimes it looks like the enhancements are overdone. Now that I got my gripes out of the way, this film remains campy fun. Bette Davis has some great lines, especially the one about the world losing all its standards and tastes. She seems more concerned about her family's reputation and social standing than she does about her Granddaughter  killing a man. Susan Hayward has a vocal attack second to none, though her role as an overgrown sex kitten is a little hard to believe. Joey Heatherton does her best, but her worst problem is her whiny voice. Mike Connors, in his pre-"Mannix" TV days, is, as Hayward's character states, "the only sane one here." Even in the flashbacks of his drunken episodes, he does'nt seem to be all bad. There is enough camp, bad acting, and worse dialogue to make this a fun film.
summary: Good Film - but Lousy DVD Transfer

reviewText: Susan Hayward is beautuful ,glamourous and talented in one of her last starring roles.Top billed over Bette Davis  (in 1964 Susan Hayward was still a top box office attraction,bigger than Bette Davis ,in spite of Davis recent hit "Whatever happened to Baby Jane".there are few scenes between the two legends ,but when they are are both on screen "facing each other"  it's fire.And Hayward is not afraid of her "mother"/co-star Davis...to say the least :-)Hayward is more on spot than Davis though who overacts (in a nice way though:-) in most of her scenes....a big splash,old fashioned,a bit trashy but extremely enjoyabe as a whole...and again two top glories of golden Hollywood Hayward and Davis as mother and daughter !!A must have for me.
summary: Susan Hayward  better than Bette Davis!

reviewText: This is a terrific drama about a teenage girl who murders her mother's lover (sound familiar?) Susan Hayward and Bette Davis star in this gripping drama, where the shocking truth isn't revealed until the end. Dealing also with the beginning and disintegration of marriage, the subject matter is handled tastefully. What keeps me from giving this film the full rating is that Ms. Davis' screen time was limited. Great performances, though. Worth several viewings, but there are better movies STARRING Bette Davis, such as "All About Eve." Not Rated.
summary: Terrific Drama. Pity That Ms. Davis Has Little Screen Time, Though.

reviewText: I purchased this DVD the day of it's release. This movie is a favorite of mine. I do not possess the technical vocabulary necessary to give an informed appraisal of this DVD transfer, but I'll try my limited best. My hearing is not as acute as it used to be, but the sound appears to be crisp, clear Mono. Picture quality which was not at all bad on the factory VHS is slighlty better here. It looks to me as though this film was struck from a clean theatrical release print. Best of all, this film is presented here in Widescreen for the first time since its theatrical release and this is a distinct improvement. Veteran Director EDWARD DMYTRYK's beautiful work was ruined by the pan-and-scan. Some scenes, apparently trimmed on the VHS seem to have been restored here and the movie flows gracefully in a way it never did on home video before. There are no extras.WHERE LOVE HAS GONE is probably the best trashy movie of all time. When I say trashy, I'm not knocking the acting, directing or writing. It's just that the film was built around sleazy subject matter. This film is not "campy" in the way that VALLEY OF THE DOLLS or MOMMIE DEAREST were. It's a rather engaging melodrama. A woman's picture, if you will. Joseph E. Levine had just scored a huge hit with the film version of THE CARPETBAGGERS, a sleazy roman-a-clef about Howard Hughes written by HAROLD ROBBINS. WHERE LOVE HAS GONE was the eagerly awaited Robbins follow-up, another roman-a-clef based on the LANA TURNER-JOHNNY STOMPANATO-CHERYL CRANE headline making scandal during which Lana's daughter Cheryl accidentally stabbed Lana's gigolo/gangster boyfriend Stompanato to death while coming to the aid of her movie star mother, Lana. Cheryl was acquitted of any charges at the inquest, however, the angelic Lana's off screen reputation for boozing and man-chasing had much of the public believing that Lana had actually done the stabbing herself and had convinced her daughter Cheryl to take the blame, knowing that as a juvenile, Cheryl would not be prosecuted.Robbins story starts where the real life slaying ends and speculates on a possible unknown scenario. Lana becomes Valerie Hayden, a society girl and famous sculptress played by SUSAN HAYWARD. Ironically, at this time, LANA TURNER and SUSAN HAYWARD were the queens of this type of Melodrama as BETTE DAVIS and JOAN CRAWFORD had been in the Forties. There is more irony in the fact that Susan and Lana had both unsuccessfully auditioned for the part of SCARLETT O'HARA in GWTW. LANA had become an immediate star at MGM and a WWII sex symbol while still a teenager. SUSAN's climb to fame had been slower, often playing second leads during the Forties but Susan redeemed herself by winning an OSCAR for I WANT TO LIVE in 1958.WHERE LOVE HAS GONE is my favorite SUSAN HAYWARD movie. WHERE LOVE HAS GONE may not have the credentials of I WANT TO LIVE, but it's a lot more fun and only slightly less compelling. This is SUSAN HAYWARD's movie and she  dominates the proceedings with a rather touching portrayal of a woman who tries to please everyone yet ends up pleasing no one. Valerie's main character flaw is that she is a Nymphomaniac whose talent is fueled by her sexual escapades. Remember, this was 1963. The Hayes office had already set back the cause of women's liberation about 50 years and so Valerie is, of course, punished for being a wanton woman. In one particularly touching scene, Valerie begs her ex-husband Luke to marry her again so that they can try once more to be a family and give daughter Danielle the home she never had. Luke turns her down. The look on Susan's Face and quiver in her voice through the glycerine tears are actually quite moving.Lana's daughter Cheryl has now become Danielle Miller and is played by JOEY HEATHERTON as a withdrawn, nubile social misfit. JOEY was criticized for her "perpetual squint" by one wag. To that I say "What was she supposed to look like? Dani had just killed a man!". Besides, her entire role takes place in the Juvenile Detention center with Dani awaiting the disposition of her case. JOEY's role is important, but she doesn't have a lot of screen time. I thought she did very well with what she had to work with. Joey has her best scene with veteran character actress ANN SEYMOUR as a Child Psychiatrist and she easily holds her own in her scenes with SUSAN HAYWARD. As for Joey being too nubile for 15, I remember many girls from my youth who were already women at 15. JOEY HEATHERTON told the Press that BETTE DAVIS and SUSAN HAYWARD had both been extremely kind to her.MIKE CONNORS (TV's Mannix) plays Valerie's ex-husband and Danielle's father, Luke Miller who has returned to San Francisco after many years absence after a bitter divorce to learn what really happened on the night of the stabbing. MIKE tries hard, perhaps too hard, especially as he overacts in his drunk scenes, but he doesn't really succeed. He's just not leading man material, looking much too Old and Neanderthal in appearance and with a rough demeanor to match. Detective? Yes. Leading Man? No. There's no on screen chemistry between sex-less Connors and Gorgeous Hayward although they both try their best. It's not all Mike's fault, The character of Luke is an unbearable self-righteous, relentlessly unforgiving Misogynist; even beating his wife and committing marital rape! The part of Luke Miller should have gone to the underrated JOHN GAVIN who might have given a softer portrayal.I had wondered for years about the character of Valerie's society doyenne mother, Mrs. Gerald Hayden. I don't know anything about Lana Turner's real mother but I'm sure she wasn't a rich society dame. I wondered what the point was of having this character in this movie at all? Well, duh! I finally got it. Mrs. Hayden represents the Movie Studio Mogul! Which Studio Mogul? ANY Studio Mogul. Cold, insensitive, manipulative and dishonest. All that metters to her is how this will look to the outside world and the press. In those days, Hollywood movie moguls did anything to preserve the reputations of their studios and movie stars because the Stars were money-makers. Mrs. Gerald Hayden is is played to perfection by the formidable Bette Davis. Davis was fresh from her OSCAR-NOMINATED comeback success in WHATEVER HAPPENED TO BABY JANE and only ten years older than the still beautiful Hayward. The two actresses did not get along, a fact which adds to the tension during their many on-screen clashes. BETTE DAVIS found the subject matter of this film distasteful. She signed on to this movie only for the money, something she would never have done in her prime. Bette needed the $250,000.00 paycheck to pay for her daughter B.D.'s wedding. She spent every cent of her salary on that wedding. So much for the ungrateful B.D.'s book, MY MOTHER'S KEEPER. Bette did not like the unattractive marcelled gray wig (apparently ripped from PSYCHO's Mrs. Bates) that Davis was ordered to wear in the film. She  claimed that a woman in Mrs. Hayden's social position would have dyed her hair. Bette was right, as she often was. The wig is distracting, ugly and unnecessary. Rose Kennedy never allowed her hair to go gray. Besides, Hayward looked far younger than her years, perhaps 30 years old, while Bette looked every second of her 55+ years. Hadn't Angela Lansbury played Laurence Harvey's mother mother to Acadamy Award Nominated perfection in THE MANCHURIAN CANDIDATE? Nobody ever questioned the fact that Lansbury was only two years older than Harvey. They should have allowed Bette to wear the Blond Pageboy wig that she wore in DEAD RINGER. More importantly, Bette wanted changes in the script as well, recognizing some of her character's behavior as illogical and/or unfounded. Again, she was right. Mrs. Hayden's motivation is unclear and unexplained. The part is underwritten. Several times, after being insulted by her son-in-law, Mrs. Hayden just sits there with nothing to say. SUSAN HAYWARD, at the peak of her popularity was not about to allow Bette to walk all over her as Bette had done to so many others. Susan vetoed any script changes. There were altercations on the set with Bette at one point tearing off her wig and throwing it in Hayward's face. Susan called Bette "an old bitch!", right to her face! Wonderful! Their scenes together are the best ones in the movie and worth the price of admission by themselves.My only problem with this film is that even in the flashback sequences, which take us back some 15 years, No one is ever made to look any different or any younger. Susan wears the same red bouffant throughout and Bette is stuck with the gray wig throughout. Are we to beleive that Mrs. Hayden was never young? Mike Connors is just plain too old for the flashbacks. He looks to be about 50 years old.Remarkably, the one character who is allowed to age is sleazy art critic Sam Corwin played by DEFOREST KELLY (several years before Star Trek). Kelly's work is good, sort of Addison DeWitt without the wit but again, he's not believeble as one of Valerie's lovers. He has no sex appeal. Dare I say it, he looks like a kindly doctor.Forties Film Noir Siren JANE GREER is here as an acerbic Social Worker. She does a nice job with the subtext, obviously contemptuous of Valerie and also obviously having eyes for Luke. There is some beautiful footage of San Francisco (probably second unit stuff) along with spectacular interiors of the Hayden Mansion all of which are enhanced by this wide screen version.The women's costumes by Edith Head make one wish that Bette hadn't had to wear that wig. She would have been the old glamourous Bette Davis one last time. Hayward, a former model is drop-dead beautiful as always. There's even a gorgeous Oscar nominated Cahn-Van Heusen Theme Song sung by Jack Jones. Oh! in case you're curious, Susan's white convertible is a 1963 Imperial, the height of luxury in those days. This movie may be trash wrapped in yesterday's tabloid and tied up with a technicolor ribbon but it's a good old fashioned potboiler of the kind that Hollywood doesn't make anymore. They can't. They don't have Movie Stars like SUSAN HAYWARD, BETTE DAVIS or LANA TURNER anymore.Also, kindly note an excellent unbilled cameo performance by an actress playing a prostitute who tries to talk sense into a suicidal Luke Miller. Her name is LISA SEAGRAM. She is a standout here and deserves to be mentioned by name.This movie deserves a serious commentary, backstory and an interview with JOEY HEATHERTON. Unfortunately, you won't get any of that but it's still a great popcorn movie. There were lines around the block when this film opened. This was a must see movie in 1964. It'll really take you back in time.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Take a celebrity murder trial, filter it through the grimy typewriter of Harold Robbins, then use the resulting best seller as a vehicle for Susan Hayward and Bette Davis, and you have camp treasure. Though the story is based on the Lana Turner-Johnny Stompanato murder case, Hayward and Davis make "Where Love Has Gone" their own. Hayward plays an acclaimed sculptress from a wealthy family, who also is, like many Harold Robbins' female characters, a promiscuous harpy. The blame for her wild behavior falls squarely on the gray head of her controlling mother, Davis. Thrown in are Michael Mannix, as the war hero Hayward marries, and a young Joey Heatherton, as their helmet-haired daughter who stabs Hayward's lover. Mannix is quickly buried in the rubble of scenery left behind by Hayward and Davis. Hayward, in particular, really tears into her role. Anyone who sees this movie should know that she was born to play the Helen Lawson role in "Valley of the Dolls" a few years later--though she only got the part when Judy Garland was canned. Even in her tender moments Hayward sounds like she's trying to pick up sailors in a bar. Davis, by comparison, is almost restrained. She also seems slightly drunk, like she belted back a few before she had to go on set to manipulate the other players. She practically announces her lines, then does a quick mental retreat. Poor Joey Heatherton really has nothing to do other than whine "Daddy" repeatedly and churlishly ask for cigarettes. Then again, no performance Heatherton would give on film could ever equal the drama of her personal life.As if Hayward and Davis weren't enough, check out the set and costume design. The Hayward and Mannix's mod '60s home is truly spectacular--it's like the Brady Bunch won the lottery. And look at the use of color. In one scene Hayward's scarf and slacks and social worker Jane Greer's suit are in complimentary shades of green that match the walls of the room. The only other example of such extreme color coordination I can think of is in the Barbra Streisand movie "On a Clear Day You Can See Forever." Also marvel at how everyone in the movie, including Heatherton--who's supposed to be 15--is made to look like they're no younger than 40. But what makes this movie a true "must-see" are the scenes of Susan Hayward welding. It's one of those moments that virtually define the term "camp." Yet, while campy, this misogynistic chick flick (only Harold Robbins...) doesn't quite garner the "camp classic" stamp--it's just a little too reserved for that. Still, "Where Love Has Gone" makes for fun viewing.

reviewText: I am a Johnny-come-lately in reviewing this film, so there's no need to repeat what's already been written about the story line and the fact that it is based on a real-life crime that had the country spellbound.Instead, I'd like to talk a bit about what's up there on the screen. Susan Hayward plays a successful sculptress with a huge pile of teased hair and a ton of hairspray, who sculpts with a cigarette dangling out of her mouth. When she's not working, she manages to be very sexually active, even while married. Then there's Bette Davis who plays Hayward's shrewd, wealthy and controlling mother. She is fairly believable in the role, even when sitting in the ugliest chair I have ever seen while preaching about good taste. In fact, all the sets are tacky & gaudy and thrown together by people with more money than taste. Then there's the terribly mis-cast Mike Conners. He looks more like a sleezy racketeer than an architect. He actually wears his hair in a pompador and wears clothes that would look more appropriate on mobsters. Finally, there's Joey Hetherton who has pouting down to a science. Her acting range is very limited.There's a flashback that takes the audience back to the 1940s, but you would not know that by Susan Hayward's hair style or her wardrobe. If you set aside some over-the-top acting and the tacky sets, it can be a fun ride. This film actually picks up steam as it rolls along and even delivers a few very dramatic surprises at the end. There are also some beautiful and stunning scenic shots of San Francisco in glorious widescreen and color.Unlike another review, I thought the dvd look excellent: sharp and clear with accurate colors. However, the soundtrack is very loud and the music track is louder than necessary.It's definately worth a rental.

reviewText: I remember seeing this when it was originally released, mainly to see Bette Davis in anything and also to see Susan Hayward in one of her midlife scenery-chewing roles.  Add to this Joey Heatherton (her generation's Pia Zadora, Steve Guttenberg, or Paris Hilton)!  What I recall with relish was Pauline Kael's scornful review, singling out the vision of Davis sitting in what Kael considered the ugliest chairs imaginable, reciting the line, "Somehow the world has lost all its taste!"  Watch the "breakfast squabble" scene, in which the editing causes a glass of orange juice to perform calisthenics.  Great fun, if overpriced by the amazon vendors.
summary: four stars for being boldly dweadful

reviewText: Susan Hayward & Bette Davis, 2 of Hollywood's most talented actresses, really shine in this melodramatic version of the Harold Robbins bestseller.  Susan holds her own and then some against Bette, when they have scenes  together you can't take your eyes off of them.  I agree with the previous  reviewer, Joey Heatherton was miscast in the role of Susan's daughter but  the rest of the cast makes up for it.  Highly recommended.

reviewText: This film is based on the best selling novel. "Where Love has Gone" by Harold Robbins, which is nothing more than a fictionaized rendering of the notorious Lana Turner-Johnny Stompanato murder case, in which Lana's daughter, Cheryl,stabbed her mother's lover to death. This notorious murder case was the subject of tabloid headlines for some time.Here, Susan Hayward plays the role of a wealthy, award winning sculptoress, who is a wild thing, wayward and sexually promiscuous, as her sexuality is the only thing that her domineering mother cannot control. One day, she meets a war hero, engagingly played by Michael Mannix, and falls in love with him, when he stands up to her controlling and manipulative, hoity toity, high society mother, a role that Bette Davis fiendishly defines.They marry and have high hopes, but Bette is always in the wings, controlling, manipulating, and in the end, getting her way, despites the war hero's best intentions. This causes him to become a drunk and for his wife to play around. They manage to have a child, a daughter, but even this is not enough to make them stay together. The mother arranges a divorce for her daughter with the proviso that he have nothing to do with their child.Time passes, and the scultoress goes on to become highly acclaimed, much of that acclaim bought by her mother, unbeknownst to her. She also continues to have her bevy of lovers. One night, the long lost father, now a highly successful architect, is summoned, as his now teenage daughter, played with baby doll nuances by the very nubile Joey Heatherton, has been accused of murdering her mother's lover. All together after many years, the generations are in conflict as to how the matter can best be resolved. Common sense and decency prevail in the end. Look for the so called surprise ending, which a discerning viewer can figure out.Bette Davis, and Susan Hayward are terrific in their respective roles, as is Michael Connor. Joey Heatherton does a respectable job with the role of the fifteen year old daughter. While some critics argue that she was miscast, as she does not look fifteen, I believe that the fact that she appears older is  central to the drama. Watch the film, and you be the judge.All in all, this is a moderately entertaining melodrama, Betty Davis and Susan Hayward fans will especially enjoy it.

reviewText: I bought the DVD of Where Love Has Gone in 2011 after reading the book which I found at an estate sale. If I recall the ending of the book and the movie are completrly different. I'll have to look at the book to be sure.The music score at times drowned out much of the audio. The scene at the airport in the beginning of the movie is barely audible due to the background noise of the plane...The DVD wouldn't switch from the opening credit chapter one to chapter two. I had to start again two different times on Chapter 2 to finally get it to play through.The main reason I bought it isI never saw it on cable and I'm a big Mike (Joe Mannix) Connors fan. Betty Davis' performance is excellent. There are no scenes of Susan Hayward's affair with the man her daughter (Joey Heatherton) is accused of killing. He isn't even shown.The movie leaves alot up to the viewer's own imaginations and for this the movie seems full of holes. This movie was not worth the price Amazon is selling it for. A better price would be in the $5.99 to $9.99 price range.Amazon said shipping would be close to 8-9 weeks delivery, then a week later I got an e-mail saying the movie should be shipped out within a week - I guess they found a copy somewhere..

reviewText: This film is full of imitations, some obvious and others not so much.  First, there is the obvious allusion to the Cheryl Crane slaying (or not?) of Johnny Stompanato.  Susan Hayward imitates an actress playing a sculptor.  Mike Connor imitates an army hero turned drunk turned loving father.  Bette Davis plays Bette Davis playing a villainous, conniving matriarch.  None of these three convince us of their characters through development, but because that is what we are told they are. Bette Davis is nonetheless compelling in her role and transcended the material as well as anyone could have.  Susan Hayward pretending to chisel a sculpture or fire up a blow torch (while smoking a cigarette, no less) comes across as nothing but play acting.  Far more convincing in small roles are Jane Greer (as investigator Marian Spicer) and Anne Seymour (as psychologist Dr. Jennings).  Ah for the days mental health workers could give cigarettes as a reward!  Legendary costumer Edith Head even imitates prior work; one of Ms. Hayward's ensembles closely resembles a costume worn by Madeleine in Vertigo.  Watch for it--Ms. Hayward wears an off white overcoat with a flowing scarf. Deja vu all over again.I liked this film for a lot of reasons besides the story-- beautiful technicolor, gorgeous costumes, and a true period look at the fashions of the Mad Men era.  Note that there is almost no attempt to assume a period look for the WWII era flashbacks.  The characters aren't even made to look younger in the mid 1940's scenes, as they naturally would be. C'est la vie; this movie is still worth a watch if you can overlook the Ed Wood lack of realism.

reviewText: 1964's "Where Love Has Gone", based on the sensational Harold Robbins trash novel of the same name can be seen as one of the last real occasions when women in leading roles were allowed to emote to their heart's content in glossy soap operas on the big screen. Big budget, glossy glamour flicks were fast becoming a rarity for veteran actresses by the mid 60's and this film makes for an interesting time capsule of what real glamour on screen was all about. In a double casting coup drama queens Bette Davis and Susan Hayward, playing a deeply troubled mother and daughter team were guaranteed to set sparks off each other on screen and that is exactly what happened with the two clashing repeatedly both behind and in front of the cameras. Indeed for Bette Davis "Where Love Has Gone", could be easily referred to as "Round Two", in the bad publicity stakes as she had only two years earlier repeatedly made headlines for all the wrong reasons when "working", with long time rival Joan Crawford in 1962's "Whatever Happened to Baby Jane?". Despite the troubled set and intense rivalry of the two leading ladies, I believe the end product here on screen was worth all the headaches for those involved. With the glamour and the camp appeal piled on for viewers to relish "Where Love Has Gone", makes great viewing from the closing era of the glossy "women's picture". Having only just seen this film for the first time courtesy of a dear friend, I believe it more than lives up to its scandalous reputation and trashy source material to be hugely entertaining and a visual feast for the eyes. Hollywood most definately doesn't make glossy soap operas with stylish performers like Davis and Hayward anymore more's the pity which makes films such as "Where Love Has Gone", precious relics of a long gone era of filmmaking.
summary: Screen Queens Davis And Hayward Lock Horns In Controversial Glamour Soap Opera

reviewText: As I post this review there are over 37 previous reviews here on Amazon. Amazon has an odd policy of grouping ALL reviews of a movie title (whether the release is VHS, DVD or Bluray). So many of the reviews for this title go back 10 years. Note the date of any review to see how current it is.Because most of the prior reviews go into details about the plot (sometimes with too many plot revelations, in my opinion) and acting, I won't repeat much of that here. I will say that this 1956 film reflects the "exploitation films" made by the major studios (often with Joseph E. Levine as Executive Producer. "The Carpetbaggers" (another film based on a Harrold Robbins novel) and "Peyton Place" are just two. Watching Bette Davis and Susan Hayward go at it is a "guilty pleasure" for many and Mike Connors comes through with decent acting. Joey Heatherton (in her "brunette years" is totally miscast - and not a very good actress - again, in my opinion.But here is the great news - for those who do want to see the film. This new (released February 2012) version has been newly remastered in HD from a 35mm archival print and looks great (even on my 35 year old television!). The Technicolor, wide-screen, film is bright and, except for a small bit OF "video noise" in the beginning has a nice sharp image. The sound is well balanced - there were some comments about music overpowering the voices in earlier reviews, but Olive seems to have resolved that issue.There are no bonuses on the BD - and obviously not on the DVD as well. It's just the film and a chapter option. (nine chapters I think). Olive is remastering a lot of the old Paramount films and doing a great job of it.I hope you found this review both informative and helpful.Steve Ramm"Anything Phonographic"
summary: NEW remastered DVD fixes all the technical flaws of prior releases of this classic "potboiler".

reviewText: Susan Hayward was at her peak when she made "Where Love Has Gone" based on the trashy Harold Robbins novel, a thinly disguised telling of the murder of Lana Turner's lover by her daughter.Since their are so many reviews, I am going behind the scenes. Susan received top billing and more money. Davis was dissatisfied with her role and had an uncanny knack for rolling over female co-stars. She would come in daily and stop shooting with rewrites which Hayward had the power to veto. The on set tension became so hot, both actresses had trouble shooting scenes together. The animosity between mother and daughter on the screen involved little acting. They truly hated one another. Susan refused to feed the lines when Davis was on camera. In a rage she pulls off her gray wig and screamed "F.... you, Susie. You bitch". Hayward walked off the set.The death scene at the end of the picture Davis demanded it could not be done without two pages of dialogue. They tossed a coin and in Hayward's words "Guess who won". The death scene is jarringly out of place and a bit extreme contradicting the Hayward character in the movie. Every battle of the two Oscar winners, Susan won. She had contract approval and Davis' career was on the wan. The onset feud is better than the actual movie at times, although I loved watching these two cinema greats go for the jugular on screen. Davis has less screen time but makes the most of it. Mike Connors and Joey Heatherton give amateurish performances. The acting credits go to Hayward and Davis. Hayward looks gorgeous and twenty years younger. She always photographed beautifully and gives a passionate performance as a sculptress/alley cat who uses men to let off steam.Terry RobertsonAuthorFill My EyesBroken Windows, Reflections of a Fool
summary: REAL LIFE CLASH BETWEEN HAYWARD AND DAVIS

reviewText: "Where Love Has Gone" is a gripping story about a woman's manipulation of her daughter's life in the name of love. The matriach (Bette Davies) managed her daughter's(Susan Hayward)life the same way she runs her business. The plot begins with a murder. The murderer, Danny (Joey Heatherton) whose parents divorced when she was ten, is the grand-daughter of this overbearing woman. Her father Luke Miller (Mike Connors) dropped an important deal to be at her side. As the plot unfolds, the audience is ferried on a merry-go-round of family scandals and the real reason that led to the murder. This movie is gripping not because of gruesome details and lots of action surrounding a murder, but a study on human frailities and the psychological impact of living a structured life with no room for deviations.
Title: N/A
